MY STUDENTS LOVE THIS SUPER LOW PREP REVIEW GAME! 

HOW IT WORKS:
It can be used with any content. Just display some slides or read a question aloud and have students work in groups to come up with an answer.

Have students rotate which member is the recorder. If the group gets the question correct, the recorder goes up and shoots a basket. (It’s even more fun if you make a two point line and three point line for them to choose from!) 

You can use any soft ball or even a ball of crumbled paper. I found this awesome baskets at the @dollartree (check around Easter time!) but you can use ANY basket or even a trash can!

If you’re interested in these text feature slides, they’ll be added to my Nonfiction growing bundle within the week! If you invest in the bundle before they’re added, you’ll be able to get them and all my other nonfiction resources that are coming soon for FREE since it’s a growing bundle! Link is in my profile @thecollaborativeclass 🥳

Comment below and let me know if you plan to play this with your class!

These What Doesn’t Belong Figure It Out games are THE BEST for calming students down during transitions. My students love to share their thoughts and ideas so they quickly head to their seats, turn their voices off, and raise their hands to share. 👌🏼

Not only that, I love how they teach students to respect other people’s viewpoints and they learn to understand that two people can have a different opinion and also both right at the same time. 

Not only do I use these games for transitions, but they’re also perfect for morning meeting, brain breaks, and fun Fridays!

This winter set is perfect for this time of year. You can grab it alone or as part of a seasonal growing bundle… fall and winter are included now, so if you invest now, you’ll get spring and summer for FREE once they are added! 🥳

Use the link in my profile to check them out @thecollaborativeclass or shoot me a DM saying “what doesn’t belong” and I’ll send the link directly!

This time is year is always crazy… if you’re anything like me, you might want to assign activities that are academic, engaging, but also help keep students calm! 😅

And my admin loved it too because it’s a great way to sneak in some research test prep since students have to gather notes and information from multiples sources and media types! 

If you want to try this no prep holidays around the world research project with your students, you can grab the link in my profile (@thecollaborativeclass) OR DM me saying “holidays around the world research” I’ll and send you the link directly!

I’ve ditched making new year resolutions in my personal life and swapped them for a focus word of the year. I’ve personally had great results by doing this and wanted to give my students the same opportunity.

Therefore, every January, we brainstorm different words that would work well and students select their word of the year and write about why they chose it. I hang them up and we reference them throughout the remainder of the year!

This activity is part of my new year activities resource that includes four additional fun and meaningful activities appropriate for the month of January, such as: play dough reflection and goal setting prompts, student awards for the year, new year vision boards, and a healthy brain positive affirmations activity! 

Grab this link to this resource in my profile @thecollaborativeclass or comment below “new year activities” and I’ll message you the link directly! 🎉

🙋🏼‍♀️ Raise your hand if you’re looking for books to help engage your reluctant upper elementary readers!

Over time, I’ve collected tons of Who Was/Is & What Was/Is  books and it’s the best decision I made as an ELA teacher. So many of my students gravitate toward these books bc there are so many fascinating topics and people to learn about. They’re also written in an easy to read and engaging manner. 

This series is perfect to pull out during nonfiction to talk about narrative nonfiction features. I also love using them to teach into Black history and Women’s history. 

Additionally, I love using them as read alouds during our Social Studies time. They’re perfect for making lessons interdisciplinary!

While all of my students love these books, I find that they’re especially great for my reluctant readers who are boys. 

Today at the book fair, a huge majority of my class each walked away with a brand new who was book, and they went especially crazy for the new graphic novels! 

Comment below to share your thoughts on this series! ⤵️

We are in the thick of our extreme weather research unit right now. 🌦️⚡️🌪️❄️ and I’m so proud that my students have gotten SO much better at taking notes this year.

We use the boxes and bullets strategy… students put their main idea or topic sentence in the box and then add bullets with supporting details that they find through their research underneath the box.

In the past, I’ve always had issues with students just copying word for word from their source to their notebooks.. so this year, we really focused on good note taking skills a lot. 

Every day before we begin, I reference this chart and model, once again, what good note taking looks like. Repetition is key!! 

Save this reel to refer back to later and tag a teacher friend who might find this anchor chart helpful! 🍏👩‍🏫

I always say that the Monday after the Super Bowl is the WORST day to teach. Everyone’s tired and cranky from staying up all night and eating too many snacks. 

Therefore, a few years back, I decided that the Monday after the Super Bowl would be a FUN day for my students to ease back into the week. 

This year, we are having a football day! 

We will review main idea and supporting details using my brand new resource: Tackling Main Idea.

After students complete an activity, they’ll be able to “kick” their paper footballs through a field goal made out of legos to try and earn points for their team! 

It’s a fun way to review a difficult skill and have some fun at the same time. 

Everything is super low prep and it includes 5 different differentiated main idea activities such as:
🏈 Topic Vs. Main Idea
🏈 Main Idea Match Up
🏈 Main Idea Maze
🏈 Boxes and Bullets Strategy
🏈 Differentiated Main Idea Task Cards

Here’s one of my favorite ways to promote writing independence with my students… make sure you create a recipe card for the type of writing they’re working on. I always remind my students… you wouldn’t bake a cake without following a recipe because you might forget an important ingredient. The same goes for writing! 

___________

#4thgradeteacher #readingteacher #upperelementary #upperelementaryteacher #4thgraderocks #4thgradereading #4thgrade #iteach456 #fourthgrade #fourthgradeteacher #4thgradefun #elateacher #elateachers #studentengagement #balancedliteracy  #teacherlife #iteach345 #upperelementaryteacher #iteachreading #iteachupperelementary #iteach456 #fifthgraderocks #iteach5th #elateacher #languageartsteacher #readingteacher #writingtip #writingteacher

This is a game changer for students who need help with structure and organization when writing essays. 

Create a drafting booklet. Each paragraph goes on a separate page. If a page is blank, they know exactly what they are missing and can add it in. 

This also helps students self identify if later on they need to elaborate more. If their page only has one sentence, they know they need to go back to their recipe card and see what they’re missing.

Who’s planning on trying this strategy? Let me know in the comments below!

Teacher Writing Tip: Part 3! 📝

This is one of my favorite strategies to help my students elaborate their informational paragraphs or essays. 

Each supporting detail needs a twin sentence. The twin sentences help the writers to say more about that detail. They can be examples, definitions, anecdotes, stat, etc. 

Make sure you explicitly model how to write twin sentences and then have your students try it out! This has really helped my students a lot this year.

Tag a friend who you think might find this helpful!

Need an easy way to manage who is out of your room?? Save this post to refer back to it later! 

By the time kids are in 4th and 5th grade, I don’t require them to ask me every time they need to use the bathroom or get a drink. It becomes disruptive and a waste of time… BUT I do need to know where they are and keep track of how often they leave the room. 

Therefore, when they need to go, they can sign out in our sign our class sign out book and then place one of these frames (from Ikea or Amazon) on top of their desk. That way, I can quickly glance around the room and see where everyone is, when necessary. 

Of course, with this system I set boundaries and teach into the expectations. For example, students know that if the two bathroom passes are being used, they must wait until one becomes available. They also know they have a limited time and amount of times to use the restroom, so they need to plan accordingly. (I do not allow students to leave the room during my 15 min mini lessons and they should not be going more than once or twice a block period without discussing with me).

Community Agreements > Rules! 🤩

I always think of “rules” as totally teacher driven. A few years ago, I started creating “community agreements” with my students instead. We discussed how we are a family community, and we all need to work together to agree on things that need to happen to keep our family happy, safe, and healthy.  If they don’t follow an agreement that THEY came up with, they know there’s a logical consequence. Having students create the agreements is a great way to be proactive about your classroom management.

One of my most frequently asked questions during my classroom set up was how exactly do you use your sticker station with your students?

I’m not a huge fan of rewarding expected behavior for my students. I fully believe that students should learn to do the right thing simply because it’s the right thing. Therefore, every time they line up correctly or follow direction, I don’t automatically give them a reward.

However, I do like to surprise my students with extra incentives sometimes to recognize when they go above and beyond.

Because I give out my stickers randomly and not every single time they complete a task well, it makes receiving a sticker much more exciting and I also find it helps motivate students to always do the right thing no matter what.

There are countless ways to use the sticker station in class, but here are some of my favorites:

👍🏼 When a student takes a big risk in class or works really hard to persevere through something challenging

👍🏼 When they help out a friend or a teacher

👍🏼 When they’re always on task and doing what’s expected of them (again, I don’t give out stickers for each time.. but if I recognize a great pattern)

👍🏼 Or overall when I just noticed that they’re being a really great student and community member.

Big kids need hands on and engaging activities too! Adding play dough to a lesson is a fabulous way to make learning 100x more fun and interesting for older kids.

Pro Tip: Give them 3-4 minutes just to play with it first before you start.. trust me! 

Here are just SOME ways I’ve used it in my ELA and Social Studies classes:

👉🏼 COMMUNITY BUILDING ACTIVITIES: Possible Prompts - create your favorite food/animal/subject, etc.  or represent how many family members you have/ a goal for this year/ something that went well yesterday, etc. with play dough

👉🏼 GRAMMAR ACTIVITIES: Students use play dough to make punctuation marks to add into sentences

👉🏼 SPELLING ACTIVITIES: Students use play dough to mold the letters of their spelling words or challenging spelling words that they want/need to practice

👉🏼 MAP/GEOGRAPHY SKILLS: Students use play dough to create maps (regions of the United States, 13 colonies, etc.)

👉🏼 READING ACTIVITIES: Use play dough to represent the plot or theme of the book.. or to represent a character conflict

👉🏼 WRITING ACTIVITIES: Plan a scene for your narrative story using play dough

👉🏼 GENERAL IDEAS FOR ANY SUBJECT: Create play dough “dots” and students press them down when they complete different tasks as a visual reminder or checklist

I try to keep things simple for back to school night! 

I always make sure that I prep a folder for all of my students’s parents. This is really helpful in many ways.

☝🏻This helps me easily know who attended. If their folder is left at the end of the night, I know that those parents were not able to attend.

✌🏼I put everything parents need in this folder: contact information, an outline of my class expectations and policies, a specials schedule, some comprehension questions that parents can use to help their child at home, and a sheet of paper that they can use to leave a note to their child ☺️

Then I make sure that I load all my presentation info onto Google Slides. I reuse the same slideshow every year, and only have to make minor tweaks. It’s saved my sanity since I don’t have to start from scratch each year!

I make sure that I model HOW I can use my heart map as writing inspiration to my students before they create their own. 

I included “Health” on my heart map because taking care of myself, going on daily walks, working out, and eating healthy are important to me. 👟💪🏼 💦 

Below is an example of how I might modeling using the health category on my heart map as inspiration to write about different genres of writing. ⬇️ 

PERSONAL NARRATIVE: I can write about the time I was going on my daily walk and got the sense someone was following me. I got nervous and started walking faster to get back home quickly, but when I turned around, I realized it wasn’t a person at all… it was a DEER!! 🦌 

REALISTIC FICTION: I can write about a character who experienced that same, or similar, situation as my personal narrative. 👧 

INFORMATIONAL WRITING: I can research the benefits of taking daily walks and the effects walking can have on your overall health. 👟 

PERSUASIVE WRITING: I can write a persuasive essay trying to convince someone to get at least 20-30 minutes of daily exercise. 🏋🏼‍♀️ 

POETRY: I can write a poem about healthy fruits and veggies. 🍎 🥦 🍇 🥗 🍌

SHARE THIS REEL WITH ANOTHER READING TEACHER OR PARENT. 📚📖

This is something I feel strongly about. I hated reading in elementary school and it was mainly because I disliked many of the books I was forced to read. 

But once I was older and discovered genres and authors I liked, I couldn’t stop reading! In fact, I’ve already read 59 books just in 2023! 😱 

Your student is obsessed with gaming or computers? Let them read books about Minecraft or coding. ✅

Is your student significantly behind grade level? Have them use @epic4educators and listen to books that appeal to them while they follow along. ✅

Is your student obsessed with graphic novels? Great! Have them read them all during independent reading and then create their own. They’ll get exposure to other genres throughout the curriculum. Plus, graphic novels often require a lot more inferring skills usual. ✅

Does your student always want to read books in the same series or by the same author? Wonderful! Have them analyze the author’s craft, character development, and themes among the different books. 

Reading is reading… and it all counts! Let’s help build up our readers by encouraging to read things they love! 💜

Comment TIMER below for the link to this amazing classroom tool! 🤩

This magnetic timer has changed my classroom management in so many positive ways. 🥳Whenever I need my students to transition from one activity to the next, I provide them with a materials list on the board and then set the timer for a designated time… usually about 2 minutes. ⏰

During the 2 minutes, students know they’re responsible for getting out exactly what they need. 

BONUS: If they happen to get finished and have everything out BEFORE the timer goes off, then they get to use the extra time to walk around the room, chat with a friend, etc. 🚶🏼‍♀️🗣️

But once the timer rings, all voices must turn off and everyone should be back in their seats. 🤫 

My students love trying to get everything done right away so they have some extra “free time”. 👍🏼

They also know that if someone at their table didn’t hear or follow the directions, they should give them a friendly reminder to help them out so the class can get a compliment when the timer goes off. 

Not only is this timer great for transitions, but I also use it to help build reading and writing stamina too. 📚📝 Every day, I set my timer for just a few minutes and tell students they must read or write uninterrupted for the entire time until the timer goes off. I start with literally just 2-4 min in the beginning of the year and increase as time goes on. 

This little gadget has helped so many of my students become more independent and organized for class. Since it’s magnetic, it stays front and center on my whiteboard so everyone can see it. I can’t love this enough! 😍💜

Comment GENRE for a link to my mini genre bundle! 📚📦

This week we reviewed genres by playing my favorite Name That Genre game! 

HOW TO PLAY:

📚 Introduce/review genres with your students 

📚 Display the Name that Genre card (I use digital slides when playing full class, but the printable task cards are pictured here in the reel)

📚 Students read the card/slide and discuss which genre is being described with their group. One person from each group is the recorder and writes their answer on a white board.

📚 All groups hold up their boards at the same time. If the group got the answer right, the recorder gets to go up and shoot a basket to earn points for their team. 

📚 Switch recorders each round until everyone’s had a chance to participate.

NOTES/TIPS: 
👉🏼 You can use any ball and basket… if you don’t have either, have students crumble up a piece of paper and use your garbage can to catch it!

👉🏼 I always set up a 2 point and a 3 point line.. students can choose which line they want to take a shot from… makes the game more interesting! 😏

Comment TEAMWORK for the links to my favorite teamwork slides and cup stacking activity! 🤩

These cup stacking challenge activities are perfect for helping students learn to work as a team and communicate in an appropriate way with one another. They’re also super fun!

However, I’ve realized that if you don’t explicitly teach what good teamwork looks like BEFORE trying a team building activity, it can end up disastrous and have the opposite result.

I start off by sharing my Teamwork slides to make sure everyone is on the same page about the expectations of working well together in a group.

Then I introduce students to the cup stacking challenges! Here’s how it works:

1️⃣ Students cannot use their hands to touch the cups at all! I provide them with rubber bands, yarn, and pipe cleaners. It’s their job as a group to figure out strategies to move the cups without their hands.

2️⃣ Everyone must participate and be part of the challenge. 

3️⃣ Once students figure out their strategies and are on a roll, I throw in some twists! 😏 

Twist 1: They can no longer talk! (I add this twist usually around challenge 3 or 4) This twist really helps the more reserved kids shine 🤩

Twist 2: Each student can only use ONE hand to hold the tools. This ensures that ALL students are working together since it’s nearly impossible to move the cup using the tools and only one hand by yourself. 

4️⃣ After we are done, it’s so important to reflect on what worked well and what didn’t work well! That’s how you grow and learn from your mistakes for next time. I make sure to specifically focus on what worked well or didn’t work well as a team, not just which cup stacking challenges were the easiest or hardest. 

I hope you try this out with your students! Mine always say it was one of the most memorable activities of the year! 💕

Comment 🧠 below and I’ll DM you the link to check out this favorite activity of mine. 

The new year is a perfect time to have a conversation with your students about positive affirmations, and positive self talk.

I remind my students that their words matter.. not only the words they say to other people, but also the words they say to themselves. 

We discuss how these positive words can help remind them to believe in themselves, as well as help them to create better feelings, patterns, and behaviors. 💕

Then I have them brainstorm 5 positive affirmations they want to repeat to themselves daily throughout the new year. They write them down and then complete a directed drawing of a healthy brain to remind them that positive affirmations help keep our brains strong and healthy! 

This is just one of the activities in my new year activities pack. Don’t forget to drop a comment below 🧠 so I can send you the link!

TECH-FREE CHOICE TIME FOR THE WIN! 🙌🏼🥳

I could go on and on and on about the benefits of letting your students have a few minutes each week to play without technology, but I’ll just give you a few… 

1️⃣ HELPS BUILD STRONG SOCIAL SKILLS:  This is something as a society kids need to work on. Taking away the tech and having them work and play together for a few minutes a week really helps them learn to communicate with each other appropriately and respectfully.

2️⃣ ENCOURAGES CREATIVITY AND THINKING OUTSIDE THE BOX: Some of the amazing and unique creations I’ve seen my students make with play dough and different types of building blocks are incredible! Not to mention, once they see someone else make something cool, they want to try as well. Positive peer pressure for the win 😄

3️⃣ ALL STUDENTS GET TO SHINE: Allowing students to choose a fun activity is amazing for their self confidence. There’s no pressure to get things right or perform well.

4️⃣ BUILDS RELATIONSHIPS: Because students have the choice of what they want to do and what games they want to play, it helps teachers and their peers get to know them better. I’ve seen so many students who usually wouldn’t play together pair up during choice time because they have common interest that they didn’t otherwise know they had.

Follow @thecollaborativeclass for more easy student engagement tips! 

For some reason, asking kids to jogging place and do push-ups is an instant motivator in my class. My students love a Boot Camp theme. It makes teaching difficult concepts much more engaging.

And this was totally free. All I had to do was create a slide with a cameo background, and add some moves that I wanted them to do each time they finished a page in their “training manual“… which was just main idea practice activities with a cover that said Training Manual! 

Classroom transformations don’t need to be time-consuming or expensive… sometimes you can just use background music, themed call and response prompts, and make a few slides and you’re all set and ready to go!
